text: <!here> do you guys have an easy way to do the inventory of physical disks using DRP ?

<@U8FAN7PLK> - for physical disks on raid controllers?  or the logical disks of a raid controller?  The raid plugin has a stage for that if we support the raid controller.   I don’t think we have anything in gohai currently.  I’d have to check.
I just checked gohai, it's only returning the volume of the server. And I meant physical disks on raid controller yes :slightly_smiling_face:
okay - so for megacli based raid controllers, the raid-configure stage can inventory the disks.
ok, I'll try it
<@UCW2CJ6TF> has joined the channel
$welcome <@UCW2CJ6TF>
Digital Rebar welcome information is here > <http://rebar.digital/community/welcome.html>
Hello guys, good evening. Is it possible to edit your templates like "net-seed.tmpl" or I need to clone it?
The supported way and the other way.
The supported way is to clone it, then edit it, and clone the bootenv, and reference it,.
The other way is to edit the community yaml file in the saas-content directory and HUP dr-provision.
This would get blown away from an upgrade perspective, but if you are just wanting to try something out, it might be faster.
<@UCHL0U7EH> - but the approved safe way is to clone a set of things.
Though I have a new thing in tip.  Just a second …
Nice, my question was just to confirm I am doing the correct way, thanks <@U02DGQYK1>
You can also use the “new” `drpcli contents convert`
You can unload the community and use the convert command with that content to create read-write versions of all the objects in that content pack.  It is also a bit one-way, but …
Good luck.  Let us know if you have other questions.

Hey all — I’m trying to figure out how to configure IPMI settings for my discovered machines so that provisioning workflows can take power actions. I’ve read that I’ll need to add an IPMI plugin, but the plugins page won’t load on the UI and the CLI is returning an empty list when I run `drpcli plugins list`. Any tips?

<@UCTE5HVRB> - the IPMI plugins require a commercial license for BMC based IPMI actions.  The "Virtualbox IPMI" and "Packet IPMI" plugins are free for use.   If you use the `runner-service` stage with your Workflows, this will install the DRP Agent resident on the system, and the machine will respond to power reboot commands through the agent - without the use of the IPMI plugin.  However, it can NOT power on a system that is powered off, since that requires interacting with the BMC/IPMI protocol.

The `runner-service` piece is in the `task-library` content pack, which is available in the open source.  It also allows you to run arbitrary Workflows post-installation, which gives you on-going "operational workflows" you can execute against your infrastructure, along with other system lifecycle management capabilities.  (for example, wipe, reclaim, reprovision, etc. activities)
That’s…disappointing. Seems to me that basic IPMI/RedFish management should be in the open source offering, whereas vendor-specific management (iDRAC/iLO/etc.) plugins could be just commercial.
<@UCTE5HVRB> - we always welcome open source contributions to the platform ...
<@UCTE5HVRB> for code that requires ongoing maintenance and interactions with commercial systems (IPMI  and Redfish are still vendor implementations), RackN maintains those as commercial addons.
It's not practical for us (or sustainable for the community) to support vendor specific items without a commercial model
We do offer a tiered cost model so that we can provide ala cart components and I'd be happy to talk to you about that

Sorry for the delay, we’re in a room working through an OCP eval right now, and DRP is a potential option we’re evaluating for managing the hardware. I understand your points — I’ll let you know if we have follow-up questions around this area.
<@UCTE5HVRB> it is possible to setup a trial license for access to the IPMI components - it's simple to enable in your UX.
Is Redfish really a commercial vendor as such? I mean, it's a non-profit consortium. That being said, no two vendors have implemented Redfish the same way yet.

<@UCU824PB2> - good question - IPMI is also one of those "open protocols" - and no two vendors have implemented it the same way ... :disappointed:   We have a fairly extensive maintained set of "quirks" that we have to apply depending on the vendor we ident when talking to an IPMI system

similarly - we'll have to implement a lot of "hacks" to get RedFish working equally with all of the various "tweaks" vendors give it - you'd think these standards bodies have learned a thing or two by now over the last 40 to 50 years of vendors hacking at "standards"
<@UCU824PB2> - that is my problem with Redfish.  It was supposed to make N to 1.  I argued at best it would be N to N+1, but appears more often than not that it is N to 2N.
and even so, you can't buy "redfish" you have to buy a server that supports it.   Thus, it's a vendor interface even if the spec is open
dogpile
